hints.content: Start by understanding what a subset is. A subset can be formed by including or excluding each element of the array. For an array of length n, there are 2^n subsets.
Remember that the XOR operation has specific properties: it is commutative and associative. This means the order in which you apply XOR doesn't matter.
Consider how many times each element contributes to the total sum of XORs across all subsets. Each element appears in half of the subsets formed from the array.
Think about how to calculate the XOR for a single subset. For example, if you have a subset [a, b], the XOR total is a XOR b. How would you generalize this for all subsets?
You can use a bitwise approach to handle the contribution of each bit position separately. For each bit position, count how many numbers have that bit set.

For each bit position, if 'k' numbers have that bit set, then those numbers will contribute to the XOR total in (2^(n-1)) subsets. This is because you can choose to include or exclude the other elements.
Consider the case when the array is empty. The XOR total for the empty subset is 0. Ensure your implementation correctly handles this scenario.

You might want to iterate through each bit position from 0 to 20 (since nums[i] <= 20). For each bit, calculate how many numbers have that bit set and use that to compute the contribution to the total.
As you implement your solution, keep track of the total sum of XORs. You can initialize a variable to accumulate this sum as you calculate contributions from each bit position.
Finally, remember to return the total sum after processing all bit positions. Your final result should be an integer representing the sum of all XOR totals for every subset.

questionNotes: The empty subset has an XOR total of 0.
Subsets with the same elements should be counted multiple times.
